org.timepedia.chronoscope.client.render.domain
Class DateTickFormatter

java.lang.Object
  org.timepedia.chronoscope.client.render.domain.TickFormatter
      org.timepedia.chronoscope.client.render.domain.DateTickFormatter
Direct Known Subclasses:
DaysTickFormatter, HoursTickFormatter, MilleniumTickFormatter, MinutesTickFormatter, MonthsTickFormatter, SecondsTickFormatter, TenthsOfSecondTickFormatter, WeeksTickFormatter, YearsTickFormatter
public abstract class DateTickFormatter
extends TickFormatter

Provides functionality for rendering the date/time ticks in a context-sensitive way depending on the current domain interval.

Author:
Ray Cromwell <ray@timepedia.org>, Chad Takahashi <chad@timepedia.org>

Constructor Detail

DateTickFormatter

public DateTickFormatter(java.lang.String longestPossibleLabel)
Constructs a new formatter.

Parameters:
longestPossibleLabel - Represents the the longest possible label that could occur, given the set of all labels for this formatter. For example, if this formatter formatted days of the week, then "Saturday" should be used, since it is the longest name of the 7 days.
Method Detail

getTickDomainValue

public double getTickDomainValue()
Description copied from class: TickFormatter
Returns the domain value of the current tick.

Specified by:
getTickDomainValue in class TickFormatter

getTickInterval

public final double getTickInterval()
Returns a positive value corresponding to a single tick for this formatter. For example, if this is a day-of-month formatter, then this method would return TimeUnit.ms().

Specified by:
getTickInterval in class TickFormatter

incrementTick

public int incrementTick(int numTimeUnits)
Increments date by the specified number of time units (where a time unit can be an hour, day, second, etc.). Subclasses may sometimes need to override this method to modify the actual number of time units in order to ensure that the associated tick labels are stable when scrolling.

Specified by:
incrementTick in class TickFormatter
Returns:
the number of time units that were *actually* incremented; typically, this value will be the same as the numTimeUnits input parameter, but in the aforementioned subclass override case, a different value could get returned (the typical case for this is a date near the end of a month).

resetToQuantizedTick

public void resetToQuantizedTick(double timeStamp,
                                 int tickStep)
Quantizes the specified timeStamp down to the specified tickStep. For example, suppose this is a MonthTickFormatter, timeStamp = JUN-19-1985:22hrs:36min..., and tickStep = 3 (in this context, '3' refers to 3 months). This method will return APR-1-1985:0hrs:0min, ....

Specified by:
resetToQuantizedTick in class TickFormatter
Parameters:
timeStamp - -The point in time, specified in milliseconds, to be quantized
tickStep - - The tick step to which the timeStamp will be quantized

setTick

public void setTick(double timestamp)
